name: Banda Islands Massacre (Dutch VOC)
description: The Dutch East India Company's extermination of the Bandanese people to monopolize the nutmeg trade. VOC forces killed or enslaved nearly the entire population of approximately 15,000 people, replacing them with Dutch planters and imported slaves.

mortality.note: Nearly entire population killed, enslaved, or fled. Only ~1,000 Bandanese survived. Island repopulated with slaves and Dutch planters.

rationales.systematic_intensity: Planned military operation. Coen requested and received reinforcements. Systematic execution of village leaders, enslavement of survivors.
rationales.profit: 100% profit motive. Nutmeg was worth more than gold. VOC wanted total monopoly. Replaced population with slave plantations.
rationales.ideology: Zero ideological component. No religious or ethnic 'purification' goal. Pure commercial calculation.
rationales.complicity: VOC shareholders profited. Dutch state backed company. Europe consumed the nutmeg. Forgotten for centuries.

analysis.pattern_note: Possibly the purest example of profit-driven atrocity. No ideology, no ethnic hatred - just business. VOC's Jan Pieterszoon Coen exterminated 90% of the population to control nutmeg. Survivors enslaved. Island repopulated with slaves. Dutch schoolchildren weren't taught this until recently. Shows corporations can commit genocide for market share.
warning_signs: Corporation given military power without oversight
Population seen as obstacle to resource extraction
Extreme profit margins justify any means
analysis.root_causes: Nutmeg monopoly worth killing for, VOC corporate structure with military power, no accountability to local population, European demand for spices

sources.title: The Nutmeg's Curse: Parables for a Planet in Crisis
sources.author: Amitav Ghosh
